column2: The castles of the Dornish Marches are among the strongest of the realm, and for good reason, for seldom has a generation passed when they have not faced some new attack. They were established to create a bulwark against incursions from the Dornish and the Kings of the Reach. The Marcher lords are duly proud of their history as key defenders of the realm of the Storm Kings, and many are ballads and tales of their valor.\n\nThe longbows of the Marches are especially famed, and many of the most famous bowmen of song and history are said to hail from the Dornish Marches.

The Dreadfort is a strong fortress that has served as the seat of House Bolton for centuries, if not longer. \n\nIt has a dark reputation and is said to contain secret torture rooms and hidden galleries that display the flayed skins of the Bolton's enemies.

The Great Barrow is the hill upon which is built the castle of House Dustin is built. It is said to be the resting place of the First King of the First Men. It is a sacred place to all the followers of the Old Gods.
The barrowlands is a region of wide, hilly plains covered with barrows, the ancient graves of theÂ First Men.
The wood harvested in the deep forests of the North is valued by merchants on both sides of the Narrow Sea for its sturdiness, a trait that makes it ideal for the process of building warships.

Riverrun is a strong three-sided castle. The castle is bordered on the north by the Tumblestone and on the south by the Red Fork, while on the west a third side faces a massive man-made ditch. In time of danger the sluice gates can be opened to fill a wide moat and leave the castle surrounded on all three sides by water, turning Riverrun into an island and leaving it practically unassailable. It commands a view of many leagues. \n\nRiverrun was built after House Mudd fell. The land on which Riverrun sits was given to Edmure Tully by Armistead Vance, to reward Edmure for his oath of allegiance to him. Edmure Tully's son, Axel Tully, then built Riverrun on that land.
To the naked eye Castamere seemed a modest holding, fit for only a small Lord or a Landed Knight, the truth however was that nine tenths of the castle was beneath ground.

Ironwood is a type of tree found in the North, it is a hard and black wood that is extremely durable and provides a strong material for building construction. Ironrath control the largest ironwood forest and use it as a source of income to sell and also as a building material to create their strong keep.
The Rainwood is a large forest that lies on Cape Wrath in the Stormlands. Although it is rainy, the region is fertile enough

The kingswood is a large forest that lies across the Blackwater Rush from King's Landing. It is in the southern crownlands and the northern stormlands and is traversed by the kingsroad. Originating from a narrow lake in the forest, the Wendwater is the largest river in the kingswood. The kingswood contains a private hunting area for the King on the Iron Throne. However, some smallfolk live in the forest. Although it is rainy, the region is fertile enough.
The wealth of Hammerhorn comes not from the Sunset Sea, but from a number of iron mines situated in the Hardstone Hills.

The tall castle of Skyreach sits upon one side of the Wide Way. Most of the castle is carved into the stone in which it sits upon. One can see both the fertile lands of the Reach and the desolate lands of Dorne from its peak. Some consider it impossible to assault because of the narrow causeway that leads up to its tall gatehouse, and the giant towers that guard its approach.

Casterly Rock, the fortress is carved out of a great stone hill and its natural defenses are further enhanced with walls and other structures. It is tunneled through with halls and chambers, with a huge keep at its peak. It is the second-largest castle in the realm with some of the strongest defenses in the world.

Moat Cailin is a stronghold of the First Men on the northern edge of the great swamp known as the Neck, in the North. It is one of the North's most important strongholds, though much of it now stands in need of repair. Its importance stems from the fact that it commands the causeway, which is the safe route for armies to travel through the swamps of the Neck.\n\nMoat Cailin is an effective natural choke point which has protected the North from southern invasion for many years. The remaining three towers of the castle command the causeway from all sides and enemies must pass between them. Attackers would have to face constant fire from the other towers should they attempt to attack any one tower, wading through chest deep water and crossing a moat.

The Wall is a massive barrier of mostly ice stretching across the northern border of the Seven Kingdoms, separating it from the wild lands beyond. The Wall is three hundred miles long and reaches over seven hundred feet at his highest point, although some foundation blocks in hilly regions such as near Greyguard.

Ironwood is a type of tree found in the North, it is a hard and black wood that is extremely durable and provides a strong material for building construction. House Forrester of Ironrath control the largest ironwood forest and use it as a source of income to sell and also as a building material to create their strong keep.

Starfall is the ancestral seat of House Dayne. It is located in the western Red Mountains on an island in the Torentine where it pours into the Summer Sea. The castle, which includes a tower called the Palestone Sword, guards the western arm of Dorne.
The Ironborn people's swift shallow wooden longships allow them to mount raids on the coasts of Westeros and further inland via river and streams.
The Arbor is well known for producing large fleets, for trading in peaceful times and for becoming one of the largest navies of the Seven Kingdoms at war.
The Arbor is well known for producing large fleets, for trading in peaceful times and for becoming one of the largest navies of the Seven Kingdoms at war.
Lannisport is a major bustling port, and a port of its size must have a large navy for trading as well as for war.
Sitting beneath the Hightower is a bustling port full of many ships, used for trading and for times of war.
Sitting beneath the Hightower is a bustling port full of many ships, used for trading and for times of war.
The Shield Isles have a legacy of shipmaking to combat the many Ironborn raids on their islands.
The Free Cities have a legacy of trading and war, so they must build a large amount of ships for these purposes.
Driftmark is a small island near Dragonstone, but which controls the middle Narrow Sea for its benefit.
Driftmark is a small island near Dragonstone, but which controls the middle Narrow Sea for its benefit.
A small shipyard, where some ships can be made but which gets crowded quite easily.
A small building to hold wildling troops.
A building to hold wildling troops.
A large building to hold wildling troops.
A large fortified building to hold wildling troops.
A small building to hold wildling troops.
A building to hold wildling troops.
A large building to hold wildling troops.
A large fortified building to hold wildling troops.

The Arbor is a golden island off the southwestern most part of Westeros, ruled by House Redwyne. It is considered part of the Reach, and is separated from the mainland by the Redwyne Straits. It is protected by the Redwyne Fleet, the largest fleet of the Seven Kingdoms. The Arbor is known for making the best wine in Westeros, especially a terrific red one and a gold wine. Wine from the Arbor is usually sweeter than wine from Dorne. Gylbert of the Vines, the legendary founder of House Redwyne, is said to have taught the Arbor's people to make wine.

The largest and most prominent trading center in Blackwater Bay, the Dun Port allowed House Darklyn significant control over trade from the Valyrian Freehold and its vast array of coastal merchant cities. It is said the Dun Port is the only reason House Darklyn can field its formidable army

The Gates of the Moon is a stout castle with a moat, a gatehouse, a yard, and square towers. At night torches flicker at its ramparts and the moon is reflected in its moat. Beyond its postern gate is a dense forest of pine and spruce, as well as the steep, carved steps along the Giant's Lance.

Runestone is the ancient seat of the Bronze Kings from House Royce. After defeating seven Andal longships during the Andal invasion, King Yorwyck VI Royce placed the heads of his slain foes along the walls of his castle.

The Three Sisters are a group of three islands found in the Bite, located south of White Harbor and north of the Mountains of the Moon. Sisterman Keep, although small and not equipped with very high walls, still protects the trade of the islands.
The man who holds the Bloody Gate holds the Vale. Over the long millenia, dozens of armies have marched upon the Bloody Gate, only to be smashed to pieces on its high battlements.
Gulltown is the major port city in the Vale.It is located in a fine natural harbor at the northern tip of the Bay of Crabs, southeast of the Eyrie and south of nearby Runestone

Heart's Home is a castle in the Vale and is the seat of House Corbray,It is located on the northern shore where a glacial river flows into a narrow bay of the narrow sea. Upriver to the west is Strongsong, while directly north is a forest.

The ancestral seat of House Darklyn, the Dun Fort was less a castle and more a fortress. It allowed the housing of an absurd amount of troops and helped establish House Darklyn's military supremacy over the Eastern Riverlands and the Claw
The Craggon Keep sits atop a large cliff, defending the area nearby.

Raventree has high, ancient stone walls with moss climbing up them. There are two huge, square towers flanking the gate and a square tower at each angle in the wall. It is also defended by a deep moat lined with stone. Inside the walls there is a muddy outer ward, a cavernous timber keep, and a godswood.The castle's godswood contains a dead, ancient weirwood of colossal size. Every evening at dusk hundreds of ravens come and roost all night on the dead weirwood as they have for thousands of years
Located between Riverrun and Blackwood Vale, Stone Hedge sits upon the hills near the river and commands the flourishing farmland and hills of the area.

Seagard is a town and castle in the northern riverlands. It is the seat of House Mallister. Located on the western coast along Ironman's Bay, Seagard is sheltered by the Cape of Eagles and is nestled near the headwaters of the Blue Fork. The castle of Seagard was built to defend the coast from ironborn reavers.

Maidenpool has a busy harbor and pink stone walls. Fisherfolk northwest of Maidenpool fish the waters in leather coracles, while others collect clams. The town has a tavern called the Stinking Goose and numerous inns, including one near the Fool's Gate. It also has a tower called Jonquil's Tower.

The Palace of the appointed Viceroy over Essos, its white and marbled walls gleam in the sunshine and from the reflection of the water. Rumor says it can be seen many miles away from sea, and would be an impossible feat to ever take it from the Viceroy.

Sunspear is a walled settlement, protected by three massive Winding Walls encircling one another and containing miles of narrow alleys, hidden courts, and noisy bazaars. 

The Threefold Gate, where the gates are lined up one behind the other, avoids the labyrinth, instead allowing straight passage on a brick path to the Old Palace. 

Rising from the Old Palace is the Spear Tower, which can house noble prisoners in cells at its top, and the Tower of the Sun, which contains the seat of the Prince of Dorne.

Pyke is an ancient stronghold. It was originally built on a cliff jutting out into the sea, but over time the cliff has eroded, leaving the castle's towers standing on series of small, barren rock stacks, surrounded by water. 

Since there is no safe anchorage at Pyke, those who wish to travel there have to sail to nearby Lordsport. 

The towers are connected by swaying rope bridges. The keep, its towers, walls and bridges are made of the same grey-black stone of which the rest of the island is composed. In the thousands of years the keep has stood, it has become covered with green lichen. A curtain wall encloses the headland of fifty acres and the cliffs around the foot of the wide stone bridge which extended out to the largest islet. The stables, kennels and livestock are located on the headland. The Great Keep, Kitchen Keep and the Bloody Keep each sit on their own islands.

 Towers and outbuildings are located on stacks beyond them, linked to each other by covered archways where the pillars stood close and by long, swaying walks of wood and rope when they did not. To get to the Sea Tower, one must cross three bridges, the last of which is made of rope

The Gardens are located on a beach next to the Summer Sea, three leagues to the west of Sunspear on a coastal road. Pale pink marble paves the gardens and courtyard. Terraces overlooking the numerous pools and fountains of the Water Gardens, shaded by blood orange trees, can be reached via a fluted pillar gallery leading to a triple archway.\n\n The Water Gardens are pleasant in autumn: hot days, cool nights, the salt breeze blowing in from the sea, and fountains and pools to admire and play in. Children from all stations and areas of Dorne are sent to the Water Gardens to foster, where they play together at the beach, pools and fountains, and in the water
The Boneway is a major pass that runs through the Red Mountains, connecting Dorne and the Stormlands. Massive keeps can be spotted jutting from the mountains and connecting to the Way.
Brightwater Keep is the seat of House Florent in the Reach. It sits near the source of the Honeywine, north of Honeyholt, east of Bandallon, and southwest of the Mander.

The Shield Islands, commonly called the Shields, are islands of the Reach. They are located in the Sunset Sea west of Highgarden and protect the Mander river from the Iron Islands.\n\n When any sign of longships is spotted, elders in watchtowers light beacon fires, which in turn cause other watchtowers to light their own beacons and spread the warning to settlements further inland so they will not be caught unaware.

Coldmoat was raised by Lord Perwyn the Proud and has served House Osgrey since. Coldmoat has crenellated outer walls standing thirty feet high with towers at each of the corners. It is surrounded by a moat.

Horn Hill is the seat of House Tarly in the Reach. Located on an eponymous hill, the castle lies south of Highgarden and a hundred leagues northeast of Oldtown among the thickly-wooded foothills of the Red Mountains.\n\n There is a pond that lies below the castle, as well as woods teeming with game.

The Mander is the largest river in the Reach. Whilst large and powerful, it is a slow-moving river, wide with snags and sandbars to trap the unwary ship. This keep rises high from the banks of the river to guard the region for miles.

Lannisport is a walled city in the westerlands located less than a mile south of Casterly Rock, the seat of House Lannister. Lannisport is located along the coast of the Sunset Sea where the river road, the gold road, and the ocean road meet. It is one of the major ports of the Seven Kingdoms and is the largest city in the westerlands.
Lannisgate Keep was built by the offshoots of the Lannister family, and is a remarkable structure, bridging the gap between two large mountains to form a very large "gate".
Lannisfield Keep was raised by the offshoots of the Lannister family to protect the farms, fields and hills from enemies.

Crakehall or Crakehall Castle is the seat of House Crakehall in the southwestern westerlands. It is located on the Searoad along the Sunset Sea, south of Lannisport and north of Old Oak. Cornfield and Red Lake are east of Crakehall. There is a large forest in the vicinity of the castle.
The Farman kings used their longships to guard Fair Isle and the west coast of Westeros against ironborn reavers from the nearby Iron Islands

Fair Isle is an island in the Sunset Sea, separated from the rest of the westerlands by the Straits of Fair Isle. The island is controlled by House Farman, whose seat Faircastle sits on it. The Crag is northeast of Fair Isle, while a peninsula containing Kayce and Feastfires is south of the island.

Bear Hall is a wood-walled castle with a smoky keep, overlooking the sea and entirety of Bear Island. The hall is built of huge logs and is surrounded by an earthen palisade. On the gate there is a carving of a woman in a bearskin with a babe suckling at her breast in one arm and a battleaxe in the other.

Deepwood Motte is the seat of House Glover in the North. It is a wooden motte-and-bailey castle. It lies in the northern wolfswood, east of Sea Dragon Point. North of Deepwood Motte lie tidal flats leading to the Bay of Ice.\n\n Deepwood is an old but not particularly strong castle. Its longhall sits on a hill with a flattened top, along with a watchtower rising fifty feet higher, the tallest object this side of the northern mountains. Below the hill is a bailey containing stables, paddock, smithy, well, and sheepfold. They are defended by a ditch, earthen dike, and palisade of logs. Deepwood's mossy outer walls are protected by two square towers and wallwalks. East and west of the castle are fields of oat and barley.

Built on the hill called the Great Barrow, and located in Barrowton, Barrow Hall has wooden walls and square towers. There is an old windmill and a grassy courtyard located near the gatehouse. Wide and wooden stairs lead up the hill to Barrow Hall's central keep.

Last Hearth, sometimes known as the Last Hearth, is the seat of House Umber in the North. It lies close to the Gift in a forest east of the kingsroad. It is north of the Last River, northeast of Long Lake, and west of the Bay of Seals. With the exception of the castles of the Night's Watch, Last Hearth is the northernmost major castle of the Seven Kingdoms.

Karhold is located along a forested river in the eastern half of the north, south of the Bay of Seals. Further to the east are the Grey Cliffs. The castle is small, but still holds up even after many years.

Greywater Watch, also known as Greywater, is the seat of House Reed in the North. It is roughly located in an eastern headwater of the Green Fork in the swamps of the Neck, southwest of Moat Cailin.\n\n It is a castle built upon a crannog, one of the man-made floating islands of the swamps, and it does not stay in the same place, making it impossible for ravens or enemies to find. Many Ironborn raiders have sunk before getting to the keep.
A roughly built structure that slightly resembles a castle, this keep is still imposing, and guards the land and waters of the Skagosi.
Pirates make their life upon the sea, hunting down trade cargoes and even preying on warships. This lifestyle has made them excellent at making shipyards.
It is here the fleets of the Sistermen are built, docked and repaired. Although meager compared to the other naval faring peoples, the ships provide more than enough ships for their way of life.
Wine is produced here for the world's consumption.
A large fortification made in the shape of a warrior with his sword raised which guards the Bay of Braavos.
A small collection of weirwood trees.
Wooded area with some weirwood trees.
Small forest densely populated with weirwood trees.
Large thick forest with many weirwood trees.

The Eyrie is an ancient castle and seat of House Arryn, one of the oldest lines of Andal nobility, within the Vale of Arryn. It is situated in the Mountains of the Moon astride the peak known as the Giant's Lance, several thousand feet above the valley below. Although small compared to the seats of other Great Houses in Westeros, the Eyrie is considered impregnable to attack. During winter years," the Arryns seek refuge against the cold at the base of the mountain in the Gates of the Moon.

The castle has five towers of dizzying size, with equally monstrous curtain walls. The walls are incredibly thick and its rooms are built on a scale that would be more comfortable for giants than humans. Harrenhal covers three times as much ground as Winterfell and its buildings are so much larger that they can scarcely be compared. Its stables can house a thousand horses, its godswood covers twenty acres, and its kitchens are as large as Winterfell's Great Hall. However, much of Harrenhal has far gone into decay, and many places in the castle have not been entered in decades. Bats infest the tops of some of the towers. Harrenhal is built on a gigantic scale
column3: its colossal curtain walls are sheer and high as mountain cliffs while atop the battlements the wood-and-iron scorpions seem as small as their namesakes when seen from the ground. Harrenhal's gatehouse is as large as Winterfell's Great Keep, and its stone is discolored and fissured. From outside the gatehouse, only the tops of five immense towers can be seen because the height of the walls obscure the view of them.

column2: The Skagosi took up a life of raiding, harassing those beyond their shores. Although they are by no means the iron born or sistermen, the Skagosi nonetheless managed to maintain a presence and instill fear on those nearby.
Although meager, Evenstar shipyards provide a small number of ships.

The seat of House Banefort in the northwestern westerlands. It is situated along the coast of the Sunset Sea north of the Crag, near the Iron Islands, and is only two days' sail from Pyke. It is one of the largest castles of the Crag.
The Twins, being a pair of towers, is divided between the eastern and western banks.
The Twins, being a pair of towers, is divided between the eastern and western banks.

The volcano is still active, with pale grey steam rising from its hot vents. Beneath Dragonmont are rich deposits of dragonglass. There is much obsidian seen in the old tunnels beneath the mountain, found in chunks and boulders. Smallfolk live in villages below the Dragonmont, tillers of the land and fishers of the sea.
Raised by House Peak to help the Gardener Kings to defend the Marches, Starpike is a formidable seven-pointed castle, with each of the seven points having a built-in tower for siege defense.

Built by Jason Vance upon his arrival to Westeros, Wayfarer Keep is a major rallying point for all the most zealous members of the Faith of the Seven as they wage their war against the First Men to the north.

A refuge for most of the Andals that decided to stay in Essos. Here they are the most concentrated and prepare for their final stand against any assailants. These are considered the most zealous of the Seven's worshipers. They would rather die than see their sacred home destroyed by fire and steel.

The capital of the Bureaucratic Council of the Blackwater, Rosby serves as the seat of the elected Lord Mayor (usually a Rosby) that controls the daily life of the city's populace. The walls are of a think stone and a lone gatehouse grants entrance to all that are welcome. There are many postern gates that allow the more higher officials to conduct their affairs in a more clandestine manner. Lying around the castle is a village made of daub-and-wattle huts.

A keep that sits upon a stout hill surrounded by the outlying forest, and protected by a small marsh to its south side. Darry is in no sense a formidable keep, yet it has served the noble Kings of Darry for well over a century and as such many farmers and people from the surrounding areas come to the keep to find a better life for their families.

Surrounded on all sides by mountainous terrain the seat of house Brax sits atop one of the larger hills and acts as a citadel for the entire region. Eager bowmen and virtuous knights await the time to ambush any foe that dares enter the perilous area.
A hulking mass of cliff filled with caves and which protects an entire city which rises around it. Wildlings are uneasy about Hardhome, but it offers them great protection.
The Fist of the First Men

Built by the First Men in the Dawn Age, the Fist is a hulking mountain located next to the Milkwater, surrounded by the haunted forest. The hill offers commanding views, with the slopes at a dangerous angle to the north and west, and only slightly less dangerous to east. There is a ringwall of chest-high grey stone that crowns the top of the steep, stony hill. At the foot of the hill there is a brook which enemies have to cross first.

The Dun Fort is the ancestral seat of house Darklyn, which overlooks Duskendale. the Dun Fort is a large, square keep which boasts an impressive barracks section that houses the fort's large army. The fort is said to have been originally constructed by the First Men natives as a circular hillfort, but was rebuilt by Lord Damon 'Shadowborne' to solidify his family's rule over the surrounding lands.

The Hammerhorn Mines are a grouping of several large Iron mines on the Great Wyk, the largest island in the Isles. From these great mines large sums of Iron are mined for not only the Goodbrothers, but the rest of the Iron Isles, bringing much wealth to the region.

A strong stone castle with walls 30 feet high and towers in each corner, Torrhen's Square overlooks the large lake to its south and has been the ancestral seat of House Tallhart since before the Andal invasion.

Located at the tip of a peninsula between the Bite and the Shivering Sea, Widow's Watch is a sturdy stronghold on a cliff along the frigid, rocky shore. Passing ships are spotted in the treacherous waters from its watchtowers, and the smell of sea spray hangs in the air.

The Wolf's Den is an ancient castle built by Jon Stark to defend the mouth of the White Knife from sea raiders. Ramshackle homes attach like barnacles to its crumbling black walls, and the inner depths of the castle hold a large, dank prison. Cadet branches of the Stark family have historically been granted command here.

White Harbor, a major trade port, lies on the eastern shore of the White Knife river. Pale stone walls protect the jewel of the North, extending a mile into the water and dividing the outer harbor from the sheltered side and the city proper. The cobbled streets are orderly and wide, lined by whitewashed houses roofed with dark slate. Seafood is widely available at the fish market, and both wine and whores at an unsavory establishment called the Lazy Eel.

Hornwood Castle is a stone and timber stronghold located near the headwaters of the Broken Branch river in a thickly forested area of the Sheepshead Hills, with White Harbor to the south and the neighboring Dreadfort to the north. It is the traditional seat of House Hornwood, a principal vassal of the Starks, and has been contested by the Boltons at various points.

Barely mentionable by southron standards, but mighty compared to typical Hill Clansmen settlements, Flint Keep is a wooden ringfort-style holdfast nestled in a high valley of the Northern Mountains. Sheep graze the surrounding meadows and rugged granite hills, while fierce clansmen guard vigilantly against possible Wildling raids. It is the ancestral home of House Flint.

Perched among the rolling mists and steep forested slopes of the Northern Mountains is glimmering Arrendell, a small castle keep hewn from the same gem-encrusted rock that it rests upon. A winding footpath leads up to its front gate with water rapids on one side feeding into Long Lake far below and to the south. Bordering Brandon's Gift to the north, Arrendell was reinforced from its original timber construction by House Liddle after repeated Wildling incursions.

Built by House Fisher and situated near a ridgeline of the Stony Shore's hilly upland moors, Bell Tower has a clear view of the sparsely populated villages down closer to the sea. A set of concentric earthen ditches surround the thin, moss-covered tower of stone, with a great bronze bell at the top of it. When Ironborn raiders threaten the fisherfolk and villagers, it is rung for all to hear from far into the distance.

Hidden in the wild rock-strewn highlands of the Mountains of the Moon, Svalia is a Mountain Clan hillfort originally built by the Stone Crows to guard a precarious pass leading to the rest of their lands. From this stronghold, raiding parties have harried travellers and lowland Vale lords since time immemorial. A swift stream flows past it and transforms into a waterfall, depositing a fine mist into a deep chasm where the bones of former clan enemies lie broken and forgotten.

Far upriver from Heart's Home to the east, Strongsong is the seat of House Belmore, so named for the six silver bells in its high central keep. An important Vale bastion as strong as its name suggests, Strongsong's bells chime to warn of Mountain Clan attacks. There are four courtyards that must be successively breached to reach the central keep's entrance, and crenellated semi-circular exterior castle walls face outward to the glacial lakes and snow-capped peaks beyond.

Coldwater Burn is an unusual castle west of the Fingers and north of Snakewood, with a deceptively deep stream, or burn, flowing straight through its center. A narrow bridge spans across, leading to identical fortified stone keeps on either side. Thick iron gates prevent entry, and interior ladders lead to open parapets above, from which bowmen may rain down fire upon would-be intruders. This is the ancestral seat of House Coldwater. Many a foe has regretted attempting to assault by the stream's edge, which pulls them mercilessly into its unknown depths.

South of Coldwater and north of Heart's Home, Snakewood lies at the edge of the Snakewood Forest from which its name derives. It overlooks the farmland dotting a stretch of open land by the bay, and was built with great quantities of dark timber from the forest. A long and narrow outer bailey slopes uphill to braced wooden gates and flanking towers protecting an inner courtyard, a small weirwood grove, and a rustic great hall that is the seat of House Lynderly.

A simple cylindrical tower resembling a thumb and made of old wind-battered flint rocks, The Thumb is the ancestral seat of House Baelish. It is a dreary place beside a peat bog, on a peninsula north of Longbow Hall. Arrowslits offer some defense, and an open staircase spirals around the inner wall, with servants and a kitchen on the first floor, a modest hall above, and bedchambers on the topmost floor.

An ancient fortification erected by House Hunter around their great hunting lodge, protecting the forests and foothills of the eastern Vale. Renowned for their fine longbowmen, it is thought that Bronze King Robar II Royce won the Hunters as First Men allies through an archery competition. Longbow Hall itself is of timber construction, with wooden palisades and earthen ramparts in a circular design around the lodge. A very deep spiked trench limits direct assault and leaves attackers vulnerable to sustained archer fire.

In the heart of a long river valley and cradled by a crescent-shaped series of heathland hills, Hardvale is hidden from view along the densely forested riverside road until nearly upon it. The castle is a stout and square one of ashen grey stone, with an open courtyard and four fat towers in each corner. Murder holes and an iron-barred gate lend extra strength, and it guards the lowland eastern pass to Gulltown from the Eyrie and the Bloody Gate. House Hardyng calls this land home.

The Redfort, ancestral seat of House Redfort, is an impressive mountain fortress east of Gulltown and Runestone, and north of the Bay of Crabs. Chiseled out of reddish tinted rock, and situated on top of an isolated plateau, the Redfort has a relatively small footprint but is towering in height and viewable from a great distance. The only passage to the fort is a series of steep switchbacks carved from the cliffside, and an iron cage and winch able to lift up visitors and supplies.

Ironoaks is the principal seat of House Waynwood, at the edge of a lake with a river flowing past and emptying into the Narrow Sea. Across the bay to the south is Runestone, and to the northeast is Longbow Hall. Ironoaks is named for its exceptional quality of oak wood, from which the fortress was built. It is remarkably resistant to rot, and while stonework was later used for the central keep, the outer walls are enormous logs with a moated trench all around the exterior. A drawbridge is the only entrance, and the trench is flooded with lake water when siege is expected.

Playing second fiddle to wealthy Maidenpool across the Bay of Crabs, Saltpans is nonetheless a minor trading power in its own right with a thriving salt-harvesting industry. Rickety multi-storied wooden inns and shops lean in over the narrow muddy streets, which become better built and maintained as the hill to Saltpans Castle is ascended. A moderately-sized fortification, the castle is seat to House Hawick. It dominates the town and overlooks the bay where crab and fish are hauled in and the flats are crowded by smallfolk piling salt at low tide.

Acorn Hall is the ancestral home of House Smallwood, set in lush woodlands east of Pinkmaiden and Wayfarer's Rest. Though the yard and castle as a whole are quite small, there is a basic curtain wall of stone erected around it, and a mighty oaken keep at its center. Thatched kennels and stables are attached to the keep's exterior in the yard, and a regionally famous smithy and forgeworks supply an extensive soldiers' barracks that is present on the first floor, which makes Acorn Hall a nasty business to assault even after the outer wall is breached.

Located mostly on the southern shore of the Blue Fork and just east of Raventree Hall, Fairmarket is an important regional center of trade for the whole Riverlands. A key crossing over the water leads north, in the form of a wooden bridge. Merchants and farmers alike do business here, come from the rich surrounding land. Wares are hawked from the bustling town market, and a modest but well-constructed stone tower-house serves as seat to House Paege.

Pinkmaiden is a sizable settlement in the southern Riverlands, to the west of Acorn Hall and north of Stoney Sept, extending along a tributary river and receiving protection from Pinkmaiden Castle, seat of House Piper and one of the great bastions of the Faith of the Seven. The surrounding land is comprised of gently sloping hills and woodland, and the castle itself is at a sandy bend in the river, moat and drawbridge aiding defense. The decorative stonework is pinkish in color, and the front gate's arched shape is thought to resemble the womanly part of a maiden.

Near the headwaters of the Blackwater Rush is Stoney Sept, which refers to the great sept of Stone atop a hill, where bells can be heard chiming through the day, and the walled town built up around it. Directly below the sept is a small but stout holdfast of grey stone, and past that is a market square with a marble fountain in the shape of a leaping trout. The alleys beyond are filled with alehouses and assorted homes, one of which has been converted into an infamous inn and brothel named the Peach.

Upriver from the Ruby Ford and sitting along the Trident is Lord Harroway's Town, a minor center of trade and important rest stop for travellers crossing the waters north or south. Ferries pass to and from the waterside docks, and near the center of town are a seven-sided sept and large inn. House Harroway has historically ruled from an old stone roundtower keep on a rare patch of elevated land. Some distance away is the famed Inn at the Crossroads and the Kingsroad beside it, where low water levels allow passage by horse instead of boat before the Trident fully merges.

Trident's Holdfast is a strong wooden fortification within the heavily forested hills south of Stone Hedge, where a plethora of streams feed both the Trident and God's Eye. The land is elevated enough to offer ample view of the fertile riverland beneath, ideal for early warning of hostile approach. Watchtowers dot the area and can be lit when intruders are spotted, and near the highest point is a sacred grove of ancient weirwoods, rumoured by local smallfolk to be haunted by slain Children of the Forest.

South of the Neck and north of Seagard is Goodfaith, among the largest of permanent Crannogman settlements. The land here is blessed with burbling springs and teems with fowl, fish, and other creatures of the marsh. Above the water is a vast network of crannogs, manmade islands consisting of thatch and sticks and logs. These are scattered around an ancient tower dwarfing any other structure, vines and moss climbing halfway up its worn stonework, and nearby is a small patch of gnarled but living weirwoods, human faces etched into their bark.

Between mountain and river lies the land of hills, where freshwater streams flow swiftly down before merging into the languid Greek Fork. The Terricks of Wycombe built an immense brick manor here and made it their seat, above the marshes and fens where green grass and golden grain sustain herds of livestock. One side of the manor house is fortified by an exterior curtain wall, and the other presses right up to a river's embankment. Turret towers house archers, and the front gate is of dense iron bars. While not impervious, the manor is well-fortified and open to smallfolk when local villages are threatened.

North of Darry and Lord Harroway's Town along the route to the North, Chiltern Keep rests on a slightly elevated hill overlooking the swirling pools and streams of the Green Fork's tributary waters. Soft soil made fertile by silt deposits is plowed by many a farm, while the old stone keep with its lone watchtower is used as a safehold in times of war.

Here lies the tall and slender spire of Atranta, inlaid with decorative marble and fine silver veins masking the baser stonework beneath. A demonstration of wealth, this was once the principal seat of House Vance and is still held by them. From the uppermost balcony, one can spot the Isle of Faces at the center of the God's Eye and enjoy the cool breeze. Beneath that are the lordly chambers and guest quarters. Lower levels house a small garrison, kitchens, and the servants, with a stables and some worked farmland nearby.

Northeast of Castamere and west of the Banefort, The Crag is an isolated stronghold watching over the plains beneath from a rocky outcropping along the coast of the Sunset Sea. It is the ancestral seat of House Westerling, which traces its descent back to the First Men. Battered by violent storms, but in a prime position to intercept any nearby force, it is an ancient place that has seen continuous occupation in spite of costly upkeep.

Ashemark is located in the hilly terrain where the headwaters of the Tumblestone river first form, before merging into the Red Fork of the Trident. It is a major stronghold of the Westerlands, guarding a mountain pass between the Golden Hills and the lands of the Banefort. A lone road leads past a village and up a cliffside to its heavily fortified walls, with rounded corner towers and crenellated parapets. This is the principal seat of House Marbrand.

The Golden Tooth is a small but strong stone fortress commanding the hill road and guarding a pass through the mountains, and thus important for travel to and from the Riverlands. For secure passage, it is necessary that an invading army hold or neutralize this point. Furthermore, the hills here are rich with gold ore and have supplied House Lefford with substantial wealth. Vaults and mining shafts beneath the keep contain a major store of this gold and are guarded around the clock.

Known to produce loyal and stalwart warriors, the marcher lords of House Payne built a squat and sturdy castle here around their original wooden hall, each successive generation reinforcing it with their labor. At the border between the Reach, Westerlands, and Riverlands, Payne Hall is vital for repelling incursions and is much appreciated by the smallfolk who live in the gently rolling foothills nearby, taking shelter within during times of hardship.

Near the source of the Blackwater Rush, Riverspring is noteworthy for the many springheads gushing out of the fertile earth, which sustain flourishing farmland and a prominent market town of craftsmen and traders. At the heart of the town is the castle, held by House Sarwyck. Built directly over top one of the springs, it has an endless source of fresh water should a siege occur. The castle also boasts a fine godswood and an impressive study filled with scholarly books and exotic trinkets from beyond the Narrow Sea.

Cornfield is a rural land east of Crakehall and south of the mountains, where foothills soften into plains and the fields sway with corn and other grains, and livestock graze freely. Runoff from the mountains collects into a broad river, Cornfield Castle standing proudly beside it and villagers diverting the water for irrigation. A knightly tradition is strong here, where the land is suited to horse and lance, and men are eager to prove their valor against southerly rivals of the Reach.

Like Cornfield to its immediate north, Greenfield is rural and separate in both culture and geography from the mountainous hills of the rest of the Westerlands. The wooded plains are home to fruit and nut orchards, and knights defend their land on horseback. Most impressive, however, is the Bower, an immense castle built by House Greenfield entirely out of bone white weirwood. It is thus extremely sturdy, and the red weeping sap has been used to decorate the great hall in ornate patterns.

Guarding the nearby Goldroad is the Deep Den, a seemingly modest tower house with a training yard, a pond, and dark grey exterior walls that dwarf its size. This is merely the outer keep. The echoing chambers of the inner keep and vast depths of the fortress are carved right out of the hillside, converted in centuries past from a network of mining tunnels and polished to a lordly standard. These efforts were presided over by House Lydden, who made the Deep Den their ancestral seat.

Deep in a secluded valley and across a mountain range to the east of Lannisport, Silverhall shines with its pale, roughly-hewn stone walls speckled with silver. Below it is a shanty town where miners and herders eke out a living in the hilly terrain. Through the front gate, a sculpture of a peacock greets visitors, the symbol that also emblazons House Serrett's arms. Throughout the courtyard here are weirwoods, shading the path to the inner keep, and a private smelter where silver ore is refined into ingots.

The hills of Hawthorne stand above the plains and farms of neighboring lands. Gold may be scarce, but baser metals are riddled throughout the rocky terrain. These support a multitude of smithies and metalworks, and a sizable town that grew under the protection of House Hawthorne from their unusual seat of power, the Sable Circle. It is a wooden keep, brownish black in color and round in design. There is an inner courtyard open to the sky and filled with hawthorn trees, which flower beautifully and shelter songbirds that feed on their ripe berries.

On a peninsula south of Fair Isle and west of Casterly Rock, Kayce is comprised of a walled market town of many wattle and daub homes, with a lesser number built of the same vibrant red sandstone as Kenning Keep, the seat of House Kenning. It is a small seaside castle, and quite striking - especially during sunsets. Down the road and past a postern gate is a series of stone piers, where ships dock for trade. While no competition for Lannisport across the bay, it serves both the castle and town well enough, and has been fortified against Ironborn raiders.

East of the God's Eye lake where the waters form into the Blackwater Rush, there is a small settlement along the road called the Sow's Horn, shadowed by a towerhouse of substantial size and made of stone walls eight feet thick. Scores of men-at-arms are stationed here, and peasants work the open fields under the protection of House Hogg and their landed leal knights.

Stokeworth is an agricultural powerhouse located in the bountiful, lightly forested plains north of Rosby. House Stokeworth commands the castle here, which is more of a manor house with substantial fortification in the form of turret towers and an iron-barred gatehouse. Crossbowmen watch the horizon, and household knights may sally out from a small first floor barracks.

South of Maidenpool and west of Duskendale, The Antlers is an unassuming square stone keep in a bowl-shaped valley where streams deliver fresh water into the God's Eye, and the woods teem with plentiful game, deer among them. House Buckwell reigns here, a family of skillful huntsmen. Outriders and rangers patrol the surrounding land for their lord, ensuring against poachers and bandits alike.

The Whispers is an ancient triangular castle with square corner towers, built of unmortared stone overgrown by red ivy. It is located at the eastern edge of Crackclaw Point on a cliff overlooking the Narrow Sea. A lone road weaves between soldier pines and weirwoods towards it, up along the cliffside to its curtain wall. One tower nearest the sea rises above the rest, lit by a beacon fire to guide passing ships, and eerie echoes are heard from within the keep, where waves pour into the caverns below. \n\nAccording to legend, these noises are from the victims of Clarence Crabb, fabled lord and knight who brought the severed heads of his victims to his woods witch wife, who reanimated them as disembodied counselors that would talk amongst themselves and offer advice in hushed tones and whispers.

On the northern side of Crackclaw Point at the end of a road from Maidenpool is the ancestral land of House Brune, a family of First Men origin who command the Dyre Den and historically brought peace to the area. Their castle is a small one that has gone through periods of disrepair, with worn walls and three crooked towers. Despite this, it continues to be an important stronghold protecting the scattered settlements of smallfolk, wary of outsiders, who harvest the local soldier pine and tend their farms.

Immediately north of the major trade port of Duskendale, Rook's Rest is a coastal town fishing the sea and bringing in food from the hinterland nearby, where farms and smallholds dot the area. Skirmishes have historically broken out with some regularity between native Crackclawmen and encroaching Duskmen settlers, and House Staunton maintains order from their stone fortress, a set of two walled keeps with a gatehouse and twin archer towers between them. The larger keep houses a soldiers' barracks and training yard, and can bring in supplies from a small waterside pier, down a muddy footpath past a postern gate.

Benefiting from its natural harbor and position in the Narrow Sea, Driftmark is a regional center of trade where the merchants of Essos and Westeros meet, dealing in spices and other goods both mundane and exotic. House Velaryon, distant but noble scions of Valyria, rule the island from Driftmark Castle, which stands at the base of an immense volcano. The walls are of dark stone and the roofs of burnished copper, modeled after architecture from Valyria itself. While beautiful, it is somewhat damp and cramped.

Huddled at the end of the Massey's Hook peninsula and watching over the choppy waters of Blackwater Bay, Sharp Point juts out upon a coastal hillside hundreds of feet above the rocky shoreline below. It is a small keep, but quite defensible owing to its location, and can only be assaulted from one side. The exterior walls are lined by protruding spikes, and a great domed watchtower within garrisons men while also doubling as a lighthouse, the fire atop burning day and night.

East of Bronzegate, Haystack Hall is a holdfast in a forest clearing close to the waters of the Straits of Tarth. It is a humble keep built from white limestone, with a small courtyard and four square corner towers. Between patches of forest are a number of hamlets and vast fields of wheat and other grasses, which are baled into hay for grazing sheep and cattle.

North of Storm's End and west of Tarth, Parchments Castle sits by the waterside between the ocean and mildly sloping plains stretching as far as the eye can see. It is buttressed by a strong sea wall, but otherwise simple in design. The stonework is pale and somewhat crumbling in places, with a central tower keep defended by several smaller towers. The smell of brine wafts in on the wind, and fishing vessels can be spotted offshore.

Bronzegate guards the road between Storm's End and the Wendwater. For this reason, it is a regionally important stronghold that benefits from some trade and the support of several nearby villages. The hold itself is rather large, with both an inner and outer bailey, a massive bronze gatehouse between them, and murder holes above it. The walls are solidly constructed of the same whitish stone as other Stormlander castles, stark and militaristic in design.

Belland sits upon a bluff some distance downstream from where two main forks of the Wendwater meet. It is a bare block of a structure and the seat of House Blount. What it lacks in elegance, it makes up for in strength. The walls of the keep and outer wooden palisade are both quite thick, protecting a village within and one side of Belland bridge, which is an important land crossing between Shipbreaker Bay and the Blackwater. A toll is collected here, and logging operations from the Kingswood transport timber by barge from the waters below.

Waterperry is the primary stronghold of the Wendwater, between Massey's Hook and the shores of the Blackwater. Originally a lordly manor house, it has been expanded by a line of Wendwater kings into a formidable citadel overseeing the surrounding plains and farmland. Contained inside the crenellated walls are a sept, a small brook with its own water mill, and lush formal gardens. A secondary keep separates the village from the private estates of House Wendwater, command of which is occasionally bestowed upon loyal vassals.

The fortress of Fellwood can be found at the southern edge of the Kingswood, where morning mist gathers over softly trickling streams and moss blankets the landscape. It is the ancestral home of House Fellwood, who constructed the stalwart timber keep that is now worn with age and overgrown by climbing vines seeking the sun. An old weeping-faced weirwood can be found within the walls, a survivor among the sad stumps where at one time Andal invaders made their mark.

Small but strong, Griffin's Roost is located on a lofty crag jutting out from the shore and offering comprehensive views of the countryside. The castle lies surrounded by red stone cliffs on three sides, which descend into the stormy waters of Shipbreaker Bay. The land-facing approach is a long natural ridge called the griffin's throat. The entrance to the griffin's throat is guarded on one end by a gatehouse, and by the castle's main gate and two tall round towers on the other end. A well-provisioned garrison can hold the castle against twenty times as many men. \n\nBesides faded tapestries, Griffin's Roost is decorated with arched windows displaying myriad diamond-shaped panes of red and white glass, and the great hall contains the carved and gilded Griffin Seat where countless generations of Conningtons have ruled. Also within the castle are stables, an armory, barracks, and a maester's tower with a rookery. A secret stair under the northwest tower goes to a hidden cove beneath the crag, which appears when the tide is out.

Located in the heavily-forested slopes at the western edge of the Rainwood, the Crow's Nest is a strategically important castle guarding a pass against forces in either direction. It is the ancestral seat of House Morrigen, who built the imposing two-leveled keep for this very purpose, roofed in green-hued slate and constructed of mortared stonework. It is further bolstered by gate houses and watch towers on opposite ends of the outer wall. The courtyard contains detached barracks and stables, and the first floor of the keep has guest quarters and a feast hall. A spiral stairway leads up to a bridge which serves as a chokehold during last-ditch defensive efforts, with the lord and his family's chambers past it.

Lockport's history is one of competition with neighboring Stonehelm to the west and the Weeping Town to the east, all vying for trade within the Stormlands and Dorne. It is a regionally prominent market town and port that has at various times extended its dominion over the Slayne, a major river route known for its rapids and waterfalls. The western portside of town bustles with activity under the watchful eye of House Herston from a formidable seaside bastion, pentagonal in shape and armed with imported Myrish-crafted ballistae facing outward to thwart attack by ship.

The Weeping Town is a wooden-walled market town with a thriving port that handles much of the Stormlands' trade, despite the gloomy weather and rough waters of the surrounding Sea of Wrath. Mud and grime stain the slant-roofed homes crowding over the crooked alleys, and at the edge of town is the Weeping Tower. It is a wooden structure with tiered defensive platforms overhanging the walls, and its great height coupled with an unstable foundation has caused it to slump to one side. House Whitehead has their seat here. Down by the docks, a number of inns service travellers with rooms, sour ale, and sourer wenches.

Deep within the Rainwood between the Weeping Town and Rain House is Mistwood, a short stone-and-timber square keep that is dominated by an immense round tower rising out of its open, central courtyard called the Tower of Owls. The very top of it reaches into the low-hanging clouds that roll like a foggy sea above the canopy of rainwood trees, which are giants in their own right. A rookery and private lord's solar are found here, with barracks and the bedchambers of House Mertyns down beneath. Instead of external watchtowers, a network of rope and plank bridges span across the trunks of trees surrounding the keep, also granting clear sight of some neighboring farmland.

Rain House is the shield of Shipbreaker Bay and the eastern Rainwood, a vital point of contention for any invading force. It is not so much a house as a military stronghold, reinforced throughout the ages by House Wylde. Its yellowish sandstone walls are built from the protruding cliffside that it rests upon, with corner spires granting full view of a natural cove and small shipyard. During tidal shifts, dangerous whirlpools threaten to sink boats and small ships passing by, and the tops of the spires are lit at these times.

Greenstone is the only fortification of any note on the remote isle of Estermont, situated on a mountainous ridgeline along the spine of the land. It is a steep climb and quite cramped, but the position is prime for swift warning of any impending assault. The walls and rectangular keep are constructed of an iridescent emerald-shaded stone found nowhere else, which has been dulled to a pale green by intense storms charging in from the Narrow Sea. Down by the shore is a narrow inlet with enough space to shelter docks, a small fleet, and a garrisoned wooden watch tower.

Tarth is an island off the eastern coast of Westeros, also known as the Sapphire Isle for the striking blue sea in which it sits. The interior is a place of beauty, having abundant waterfalls, soaring mountains, high meadows, and shadowed vales. It is also a source of marble, a valuable export, and the principal decorative material used for pillars and flooring in the great hall of Evenfall Hearth, a coastal stronghold of colossal size that is the seat of House Tarth. The head of this Andal family is known as the Evenstar, a tradition dating back to the dawn of days. \n\nThe castle's exterior stands proud and tall, jutting right up to the edge of a precipitous cliff of jagged rocks. There is a low outer wall and a much higher main wall with double towers in each of its four corners, and a trio of turrets above the central keep linked by an elevated, arched walkway. A steep, hidden stairwell leads down through the dungeon to a hollow cavern with a chained boat and locked iron grate, accessible but unseen by sea.

Old Oak is an ancient castle along the Searoad, south of Crakehall. It is the seat of House Oakheart, an old noble line descending from Garth Greenhand, mythical high king of the First Men. The castle hunkers behind a tall curtain wall, a dry moat, and dual gates leading under a barbican. Inside the courtyard can be found shade beneath branching oaks and a cool dip in shallow pools, and a small temple with stairs going down to the fastidiously maintained Oakheart crypt. The main keep has pointed conical corner towers, an open balcony extending from the uppermost floor, and a large great hall with green and gold banners hanging from wooden support beams. Murals of the family's esteemed history are visible throughout.

Goldengrove is a place of serene natural beauty, with sun-drenched fields and orchards stretching across the land and a gentle river flowing through it. It is the home of House Rowan, who trace their ancestry back through Rowan Gold-Tree to Garth Greenhand. According to legend, she was so bereft when her lover left her for a rich rival that she wrapped an apple in her golden hair and planted it upon a hill. From the apple grew a tree whose bark, leaves and fruit were yellow gold. \n\nThe castle defending this realm is situated beside the riverfront, where willows droop and sway in the breeze. It is small in stature but well-constructed, garrisoned by spirited soldiers and knights drawn from the countryside.

Grassy Vale sits along the northern shore of the Blueburn river, in the lowland valley just past its source in the hills. Intense patches of many-colored wildflowers grace the verdant soil here, the likes of which are emblazoned upon House Meadows'coat of arms, who rule from their seat of Grassfield Keep. It is a two-storied building with stately gardens and a large iron-gated private grounds separating it from the two villages it lies between. The first floor is stone, housing the stables, larder, and servants'quarters, and on the rustic timbered second floor is a hall, bedchambers, and lord's study.

Stonebridge is situated where the Roseroad crosses the Mander, taking its name from the old stone bridge curving upward over the rough, muddy waters. Only shallow boatcraft can navigate here, and fording is unwise. House Caswell presides over toll collection and more lordly duties from their castle, which has a squat stone-and-timber framework, seeming taller than it is from the flat, low-lying terrain. Despite its diminutive height, its battlements are broad and unyielding, and it serves as an important bastion and tactical choke point against any invading force.

Longtable stretches north to south along the river Mander near its confluence with the Blueburn, just south of Stone Bridge. As with many areas of the Reach, it is a bounteous land based on agriculture and supporting a large populace, which has historically conferred substantial wealth to House Merryweather. Their traditional seat is a long, rectangular keep built of mortared rocks hoisted from the riverbed, mottled grey and brown and stacked three stories high. The outer wall is rather low by comparison, but reinforced with a steep earthen trench. Entering through the gatehouse, the path is lined by gardens where fruits both foreign and native ripen solely for the lord's pleasure.

Tumbleton is a major population center and prosperous inland town of the Reach, sprawling out across both sides of the Mander near its headsprings. As the largest settlement in the Northmarch, which borders frequently hostile neighbors, it has been a target of attack throughout its history, leading to full encirclement by an outer wall and progressive reinforcement of Footly Keep, a stout but small castle with a garrison of well-drilled archers, pikemen, and mounted outriders. \n\nThe town itself is a crowded place, filled with merchants hawking wares from brightly-colored stalls and pavilions in the cobbled market square, which is shadowed by the Tumbletower, a tall but crudely wrought structure where prisoners are held and executed, often by taking a tumble from above with a noose and left to hang upon the wall, reminding onlookers about the rule of law.

Honeyholt is a fertile land that has been occupied since the dawn age, situated along the eastern bank of the languid, slow-moving Honeywine river between Oldtown and Brightwater Keep. This entire region is considered the agricultural capital of the Reach. Seated here in Honeyholt is House Beesbury, an old family with a history of bee-keeping dating back to its founder. \n\nThey command this section of the Honeywine from their castle by the river, separated from an adjacent village by a long drawbridge and deep moat, with high stone walls of a chalky white hue that gleam in the sun. There are many apiaries in the wildflower-rich fields and orchards, which also support a booming trade in mead, the finest of which is exported or kept in the lord's private stock.

Bandallon is a castle keep at the confluence of a northern branch of the Honeywine river that empties into the nearby Sunset Sea. Having suffered far-ranging Ironborn raids that slipped past the Shield Islands to the north, it was fortified as a major stronghold for the area, with an iron-barred portcullis and circular outer walls, the battlements of which are machicolated and reinforced by three flanking towers. \n\nThe inner keep was originally a dilapidated two-storied manse - it was later renovated and had a third floor added by House Blackbar, with a large candle-lit sept enclosed by an arrow-slitted walkway. The first floor was then converted to barracks, and in between are the private chambers and feast hall.

Blackcrown is a castle of dark stone, resting atop a sloping hill at the edge of an estuary on the north shore of the Whispering Sound, with its brackish water, wading birds, and flocks of gulls. The castle is resident to House Bulwer, a noble family descended from Garth Greenhand through his mighty son, Bors the Breaker. According to legend, Bors gained the strength of twenty men by drinking only bull's blood. Some tales state that he grew a pair of black horns from this. \n\nIn any case, Blackcrown is a vital point defending the rich farmland nearby, where milk cows graze, and fire plums and fortified plum wines are produced in copious amount. Together with the Three Towers across the bay, it has also served as an auxiliary fortress guarding against hostile approach to Oldtown.

Sitting astride a prominent cliff on the southern shore of the Whispering Sound, Three Towers is a defensible walled fortress with a gargantuan trio of towers, one of which serves as the central keep. The two others reinforce both western corners overlooking the shoreline, imposing trebuchets assembled atop them denying seaborne assault. Ballistae line the wall facing the east, bolts peeking out between the crenellations ready to brutally impale attackers climbing the hillside approach. \n\nHouse Costayne has their seat here, sworn to Oldtown and guarding it alongside Blackcrown across the bay. The land is densely populated and overflowing with agricultural productivity, which supported Three Towers'construction.

Sunhouse is the most southerly Reach stronghold on the mainland of Westeros, situated east of the Redwyne Straits and west of the Torrentine's mouth in borderlands that have witnessed numerous incursions from Dorne throughout history. No doubt invaders are envious of the wide plains, ripe crops, and swaying sunflower fields pressed for their valuable oil. The sunflower lends its form to House Cuy's coat of arms, and its name to Sunflower Hall, the ornately decorated great hall within Sunhouse full of colorful paintings, marble statues, and a plush velvet carpet of blue and yellow leading to the Sunflower Seat - a ceremonial wicker chair on a dais where the lord receives audience. \n\nBeyond tall sandstone walls and spires erected in the Dornish style by a former occupying force, the town of Cuy sprawls all the way to sea, a hub of trade and stopping point for vessels on route to Oldtown or The Arbor.

Blackmont is a castle perched on a peak overlooking the village below, like the great black vulture emblazoned upon House Blackmont's coat of arms. It lies on the eastern banks of the Torrentine river, where rushing rapids and rocky canyons stretch south towards Starfall, and is considered a bastion of The Vulture faith within the Red Mountains. The walls and watchtowers are built of brown sandstone, and the lofty keep is roofed with a darker shade of slate. From this point of power, many raids have been launched into the Dornish Marches and beyond.

High Hermitage lies directly north of Starfall and was founded as a monastic retreat with its own septry, in the craggy highlands of the Red Mountains. Intended for quiet contemplation and simple living, it experienced repeated attacks during marcher conflicts and has fallen under the protection of various lords of the Faith who reinforced it with a formidable outer bulwark. Tended olives grow outside under intense sun, gnarled and dusty, while the septry and inner grounds are housed halfway beneath an overhanging canyon, where some buildings are carved right out of the rock face.

Follow the Wide Way south of Skysreach, past the Prince's Pass, and you will come to King's Grave. This is where the founder of House Manwoody slew a king of the Reach in ages past, and the whole area derives its name from this notorious act. \n\nDown the slope of a mountainside on a level field is found the castle, square in shape and tan in color, with tiled red roofs on its conical spires. A broad cloth pavilion is staked into the courtyard, where smallfolk from nearby villages bring tribute to the lord. Itinerant shepherds and their sheep are found along the sweet meadowland of a nearby river, which flows east to Yronwood.

Vulture's Roost is an ancient stronghold of The Vulture faith, near the source of the river Wyl deep in the Red Mountains. The air here is crisp, cold at night, and strong winds blow dust through. Broken stones dot the landscape, and a harsh sun beats down onto bleached white bones picked clean by carrion birds. \n\nSome fertile land is found by the waterside, however, and the redstone keep of the Vulture's Roost guards it from atop a western hillock. It is a squat and stout thing, mortared by mud and crumbling in places, but it is a defensible location and reinforced by dry outer trenches. Fallen men lie in piles here, desiccated and contorted into frightful poses from their moments of death, ready to cast doubt upon the hearts of any whom approach with ill intent.

Alone in the Sea of Dorne is the arid isle of Ghaston Grey. It is a small, bleak place with an old fortress carved from greyish sandstone and topped by rusting iron spikes along its battlements. The Grey Tower prison here is most notorious, where criminals are sent by neighboring kingdoms to rot into dust and bone. The lord receives just compensation for this, which sustains his family, a meager garrison, and the squalid sustenance of its shackled forsaken men. Beauty is found only in the distant sky during sunset, where many shades of purple, red, and pink greet the azure water at its horizon.

Sandstone was settled by Andal adventurers who ventured into the deep dunes and sands, east of Starfall and west of Hellholt. Prominent among them was House Qorgoyle, who fortified the only well around for fifty leagues by constructing defensive walls around both it and a pale sandstone keep. The grated front gate is typically open to smallfolk and weary travelers, who gather from it for their needs under the watchful gaze of household guards. A small village sprawls from the gate entrance outward towards a seasonally dry stream, the mud bottom cracked and fissured by heat.

Hellholt is a grim castle that stinks from the warm, sulphurous waters of the river Brimstone, which flows south from its mountain source and empties into the Summer Sea. The castle rests by its embankment, sloping down the mountainside from a crest overlooking the endless sands. The outer wall follows the water before curving away, forming a narrow rectangular courtyard with towers at each corner. \n\nA dusty path leads from the bottom gatehouse upward to the ridgeline and the lord's keep, a tall square structure built by House Uller from an unsightly, pitted mixture of yellow sandstone and brown rock, with arrow slits and claw-shaped balconies on the second floor. Pleasant to gaze upon, it is not, but only the foolhardy doubt its strength.

The Vaiths built a tall and pale castle in the hills east of the restless dunes of Dorne, in a prime location to control one of the two tributary waterways feeding the great Greenblood river. It is considered their principal seat and a major Dornish stronghold, its construction aided by lucrative trade in the populous town that grew outside its walls, where dyes, silks, and other luxuries exchange hands in the colorful market square. \n\nGuardsmen patrol with scimitar and spear, ready to break up trouble or man the battlements against assault. Swift sand steeds are also bred here, whinnying from the stables, and travelers may rest by fragrant gardens with fountains and marble pillars in imitation of the famous Water Gardens near Sunspear.

Salt Shore is a region in southern Dorne stretching along the coast of the Summer Sea, where fishing boats with their billowing sails harvest from the warm waters and larger trading vessels are spotted in the distance. Smallfolk may be found piling pinkish salt along the shore and hauling it off for trade. Further inland and set upon a rocky windswept cliffside is a round sandstone keep with an open inner courtyard shaded by date palms, and decorative geometric patterns carved into the walls. \n\nThere is an interior walkway circling the entire second floor, and many shuttered windows from which bowmen may loose arrows and the surrounding land can be viewed. Sun-faded banners hang from exterior wooden structural planks, showcasing the heraldry of House Gargalen.

Godsgrace is an important stronghold sitting near the junction of the Greenblood river, right along the shore where walls extend deep into the water. There is a large open area in between to receive supplies during siege, with twin docks following the walls before ending at fortified stone watchtowers, barnacles clinging to their base. Should hostile ships be lured in, hidden chains are dredged up from the riverbed here to entrap them. The tall, rectangular main keep is pushed up against the landward northern wall, jutting above it, and a gatehouse riddled with murder holes tunnels directly beneath. This is the seat of House Allyrion, and in their own words, no foe may pass.

Lemonwood lies south across the Greenblood from Planky Town, near the river's mouth. Lemon, lime, and blood orange trees thrive in the sandy loam soil here, which is irrigated by a spider's web of thin canals. They are able to withstand the heat that would wither other plants, providing a valuable resource to the people here. \n\nAmong the many orchards is Lemonwood Manor, a small square building that is the seat of House Dalt and decorated in the Dornish style. The hall is noteworthy for an ornately carved wooden throne chair, where smallfolk entreat the lord's favor and seek dispute resolution after ceremonially scattering sweet-smelling blossoms at his feet.

The Tor is a traditional seat of Dornish kings from House Jordayne, ruling from a triangular sandstone castle situated on the bare ridgeline of a rocky mountain chain that follows the Greenblood inland. Sight of both the river and northern coastline is possible here on clear days, and surprise assault by foreign armies is nigh impossible while controlling The Tor. \n\nIt is of substantial strategic importance for this reason, and has been fortified in recognition of this - the walls are thick, supporting a trio of tall flanking spires at each point. These are manned by watchmen and a contingent of archers. A ditch has also impressively been dug from the hard soil and lined with spikes, completed by a drawbridge and narrow gatehouse where a few ranks of spearmen can repel a far larger force.

The Greenblood circulates most trade within eastern Dorne, and Planky Town is its pumping heart, located west of Sunspear near the river's mouth. Merchants from across the Narrow Sea do business at the harbor, where barges small and large are lashed to a jumbled network of docks. Some are permanently tied up and anchored, converted to homes and businesses. It is thus a swelling mass of people and activity, and travel by pole boat is a common alternative to walking. \n\nDuring celebrations, sour Dornish red wine flows as freely as the Greenblood, there are cheers over competitive games of cyvasse, and song carries across the water. Commanding this boisterous town is the Creaky Keep, a hulking wooden fortress that watches over the floating market square from land, holding a respectably sized garrison, a great hall, and lordly quarters above.

Ghost Hill is a castle of chalk-white walls, shining against the deep blue of the Sea of Dorne. It is near the top of a gently sloping hill, walled off from a small town that spreads all the way down to the base. While historically possessing few resources besides sparse hardwoods, some rudimentary agriculture, and the haul of nearby fisherfolk, it has importance as a sea to caravan route less vulnerable to piracy from the Stepstones, which many ship captains are disinclined to risk. Traversing the dryland and desert is thus a fair tradeoff on the way to Planky Town or Sunspear. \n\nAnother unique aspect of this area is the presence of numerous slot canyons, the soil so compacted that it floods from rare rains. These are locally rumored to be haunted by ghostly specters of the drowned, their wails bemoaning such an unexpected death in this parched land.

Spotswood was first settled by the Santagars, adventuring Andals who stumbled upon a precious spring feeding into a sheltered coastal lagoon occupied by Stepstone pirates. In gratitude to the gods after victoriously driving them off, the springhead was enshrined by a resplendent seven-pointed sept walled and tiled with polished pale sandstone. From this same material was built their small but stout keep, which oversees the lagoon that now serves as a stopping point to and from the Greenblood. \n\nFurther inland is a great copse of yew trees, the material fashioned into longbows of superior quality by local craftsmen. Taking advantage of this, a tradition of archery was established, and some of the finest bowmen in Dorne are trained here to serve the lord, or alternatively as valuable mercenaries elsewhere.

The Tower of Glimmering sits on back of a rotund seaside crag crumbling away from the perpetual smashing of waves into the dark, serrated rock. An open abandoned pit may be found nearby, where once a paler workable limestone was excavated by thrall labor. The fat drum-shaped tower is built from this material, which contrasts against the barren point upon which it rests. \n\nNorth and south along the flatter sections of coastline are sod-roofed huts of fishing villages, and west are the open moors. Stacks of peat are sliced from the soil there and dried to fuel sooty hearths from the cold. Lacking even meager farms, some hardwood groves are carefully managed for longship production, sustaining continuous reaving of the vulnerable riverland that lies less than a day's journey east.

Situated on the sloping hillside of a peninsula on the northeastern edge of Harlaw Isle, a monstrous mass of stone has been upended from the earth into a set of ten towers, all of varying size and shape - some round and low, others square and strong, and a few so slender and tall that they dare the Storm God to strike them down. \n\nEach of these is linked by a maze of arched walkways and covered bridges, and at the center is the Book Tower, an octagonal giant made of large block stones and which boasts one of the finest libraries in Westeros at its summit. From this vantage, the wind howls all around, and there is full view of the Long Stone Quay, a feat of masonry plowing deep into the sea between two towers flanking it from shore. Fishing is excellent there, and ships sidle up to it as Harlawn raiders who've paid the iron price haul in their plunder to the main hall, where crossed scythes of beaten silver hang above the high seat of their powerful house.

Among the most ancient of castles on the Iron Islands, Harlaw Hall was designed principally for its defensive capability, with a concentric ring of stonework denying access to the crest of a hill and the plain square keep that sits upon it. Besides the spacious great hall, which takes up the entire first floor, it is a rather modestly sized fortification by Ironborn standards and suffers from cramped, dank quarters prone to nitre buildup. Despite this, it has prestige as the ancestral seat of House Harlaw, and the benefit of productive mines for lead, tin, and iron, transported for trade and refinement by shaggy ponies used throughout the island that are renowned for their endurance whilst navigating the stony terrain.

Langaanes is an especially low-lying settlement spanning across a long, narrow isthmus between the sea and a freshwater lake large enough that the other side is scarcely visible - a rarity for the Iron Islands. Located nearest Castamere and the coastline of the Westerlands, longships returning from reaving traditionally found haven here before moving on. Frequently overloaded with captives, a dubious slave trade was developed by House Codd, totally anathema to the Ironborn value of refusing the gold price for thralls. \n\nDue to extensive admixture of Westermen and Ironborn blood, and several major thrall rebellions, Langaanes' reputation was tarnished. It is commonly considered a place of thieves, cowards, and wanton women. The people carry on, however, bolstered in number by fertile farmland and a growing harbor, all while traditionalists vow that the Drowned God will swallow them into the depths during a great reckoning.

Lordsport is the largest town in the Iron Islands, possessing a natural harbor that provides safe anchor to hundreds of vessels, including those wishing to reach the fortress of Pyke. Its many docks dip into the chilling water like swarthy fingers, and the shore is reinforced against rough storms by embankments of stone. There is an everpresent beating of anvils from forges producing excellent swords, axes, mail, and plate - twangs and thuds of hammer on metal carry over all the cut thatch roofs of timber and wattle homes that crowd in around the harbor and up a steep cobbled street to the stronghold of House Botley, their pale green banners drooping from its squat corner towers. Beyond a low wall, the main keep is a towering behemoth built of the same timber and wattle construction, unusual for bucking the trend of reserving most wood for ships.
