At the western limit of the known world, the red glow of Lonely Light's flame may be seen atop an old stone roundtower enclosed by decaying outer walls clinging to a level plateau, reachable only by a switchback trail carved from the cliffside. The island is a tiny one, part of a meager chain of glorified reefs and rocks ruled by House Farwynd. It is rumored that they can take the form of sea lions, walruses and spotted whales, their only neighbors besides seabirds. Others say that they are prone to madness, owing to extreme isolation. In any case, their land is a true backwater leagues away from civilization, its primary asset being shallow shoals where ships may safely rest.

South from Hammerhorn across a shallow inlet, the hovels of a fishing village are strewn along the pebbled shore of a sheltered cove, just beyond the reach of high tide. Smooth, water worn stones make up the walls of most structures here, stacked up and mortared by a combination of mud and manure. At the center of this community is an open courtyard, a well, and Pebbleton Tower, the large square towerhouse seated by House Merlyn watching over the populace. Turrets rise from each corner, and families traditionally bring a collection of new stone each year, adding to its height with their combined labor.

Behold the sacred hill where the petrified ribs of Nagga, a dead sea dragon, rise from the ground like large white trees as wide as a dromond's mast and twice as tall. These are the beams and pillars of the Grey King's Hall, and her jaws the throne. According to legend, the Hall had been warmed by Nagga's living fire, and on the walls hung tapestries made of silver seaweed. The men sworn to the Grey King ate at a table shaped like a large starfish while seated on thrones made from mother-of-pearl. Upon the Grey King's death, the Storm God snuffed out Nagga's fire and the sea stole the throne. \n\nThis is where Kingsmoots historically occur, Ironborn captains putting forth their names as candidates, one to rule the land as Rock King, and another over the sea as Salt King. Support is swayed by personal combat, eloquent speech, generous gifts, or simply the size of one's fleet at anchor in the bay of Nagga's Cradle - feasting tents are raised between the tideline there and Nagga's Hill.

On the edge of Old Wyk's western peninsula is the fortress of Shatterstone, where Ironmen of old raised a tall earthen mound and set blackened stones upon its crown in the form of a colossal D-shaped keep, ringed by low walls and facing the east. Stories passed from wise crones and priests of the Drowned God speak of a legendary battle against his Storm God rival, when the spine of the island was broken and crushed down from its former height, rock and ash sent spewing leagues away to bury all in their wake. \n\nMiners in the cruel, windy hills occasionally report rubble and even preserved victims cast to stone in fetal poses, and there are those who say the war is not yet finished. From their Shatterstone seat, House Drumm and the surrounding townsfolk stand ready.

Similar to Shatterstone to the north, Drumm Tower is built of a black rock dispersed across the island. It is a relatively short round structure, but broad in girth and large enough to serve as a proper keep for a lord. It functions as a watchtower across the southerly waters, and guardian over a grove grown exclusively for warship production. \n\nYounger sons of the Drumm family are bestowed command here, which is a holy place for their lineage. An overgrown path meanders downhill to burial mounds and a ring of standing stones, hinting at their First Men lineage before the Drowned God's embrace. It is also rumored that a dead Drumm practiced necromantical magics at this site, and locals put fear into their children with tales of a lich warlock stealing those who misbehave, to sacrificially carve out their still-beating hearts.

Above the main entrance to a series of ore mines and excavated caves is the bulky square castle of Hammerhorn, with its iron spikes looming imposingly over the battlements. The stonework used for its construction was quarried by thralls from the cliff directly behind it, a feat of substantial cost and toil. The halls within are full of shadows, dank and drafty from the seaborne winds sweeping up and over the ridgeline, and the sullen hearth fires are said to give off more smoke than heat. \n\nIt is a decidedly inland fortress, rare for the Iron Islands, and the way up to the front gate is a rough one along a trail so narrow as to be unsafe for horses. Despite these troubles, it oversees the most productive extraction of mineral wealth in the region, as well as a busy harbour town in the distance.

Among the humblest of House Goodbrother's holdings is their old seat of Crow Spike Keep, a lone tower rising from within the western limits of the Hardstone Hills, where the island's backbone tapers into flatter terrain. Originally overseeing a fishing village razed by war, the decrepit husks of homes were stripped of their stone and used to reinforce the tower's base, which now houses a defensive garrison protecting part of a fleet tethered in the bay, some ships undergoing repairs while beached on the sandy shore.

One of the northernmost isles of the Iron Islands is Blacktyde, with its eponymous castle situated on a rocky seaside ledge watching out over the rugged southerly coast. The walls are comprised of solid grey stone, as is the central keep, a long rectangular two-floored structure following the cliff's edge. Beneath it are tidal pools and a hollow where rushing waters pour in, roaring and spraying sea mist high into the air. The shipyard harboring House Blacktyde's longships is a short walk from here, accessible by pulley from the courtyard and guarded by garrisoned auxiliary towers. \n\nNotorious for extremely distant raids and the taking of salt wives from the wine lands of the Reach, the people here are noted for their mixed Westerosi complexion bred in over many generations.

Primary seat of House Farwynd, Sealskin Point is the origin of the family's far-flung cadet branches. As the name suggests, it is home to an abundance of seals, using this sparsely populated land as their breeding ground. Some consider the people here to be most queer, with skinchanger's blood coursing through their veins, and the Farwynd lords are worse accused of heretical Storm God worship. No matter the rumors suffered, theirs is a proud line, ruling from one of the few wooden great halls on the isles, square-shaped and slope-roofed, and defended by a staked perimeter. The hearth is warm, full of fur-lined benches round the fire, with carven masks of snarling beasts hung as decoration, and the throne chair is of polished bone.

To the descendants of the First Men Winterfell is not just a castle, it is a legend. It was supposedly built by Brandon the Builder over eight thousand years ago with the help of giants and for most of recorded history has been the seat of House Stark. \n\nIt is positioned over hot springs that not only provide a continuous supply of fresh water, but also heats the castle and its environs through even the harshest winter.

One of the strongest castles in the realm, Storm's End was once the ancestral seat of the Storm Kings of House Durrandon extending back many thousands of years. The castle is said to be protected by spells woven into its very walls that prevent magic from affecting it or passing through it.

The Eyrie is an ancient castle and seat of House Arryn, one of the oldest lines of Andal nobility, within the Vale of Arryn. It is situated in the Mountains of the Moon astride the peak known as the Giant's Lance, several thousand feet above the valley below. Although small compared to the seats of other Great Houses in Westeros, the Eyrie is considered impregnable to attack. Its construction was started by Roland Arryn. \n\nDuring winter years, the Arryns seek refuge against the cold at the base of the mountain in the Gates of the Moon.

Casterly Rock, the fortress is carved out of a great stone hill and its natural defenses are further enhanced with walls and other structures. It is tunneled through with halls and chambers, with a huge keep at its peak. It is the second-largest castle in the realm with some of the strongest defenses in the world.

The Hightower stands tall in the center of Oldtown. It is a massive stepped tower with a beacon on top to guide ships into port. It is the tallest structure in the Seven Kingdoms and some claim that the Wall can be seen from its top.

Settled by an alliance of Andal warlords that deposed a driftwood king and dispossessed House Greyiron of their birth home, the Hoares of the black blood rose to prominence by allegedly winning the finger dance against Rognar II, seizing Orkmont Castle as their prize and losing only two fingers in the process. This granted them a bare brute of a fortress, situated above a bowl-shaped valley on the hillside, the lower portion flooded as a salt marsh during high tide. The island's landscape as a whole is barren, having been stripped of its forests long ago, and the Hoares rely on a blend of ore extraction, astute trade, savage raids, and permanent conquest against richer domains. Their sigil represents these varied historical holdings, all bound by iron chains.

Eastwatch-by-the-Sea is the easternmost castle along the Wall, located on a grey, windswept shore by the Bay of Seals. The Night's Watch keeps several galleys at Eastwatch, including larger vessels capable of crossing the narrow sea and lean fighting vessels. The galleys patrol the Bay of Seals in part to catch smugglers who trade weapons to the wildlings.

Oldstones sits on a hill above the Blue Fork of the Trident. The curtain wall of Oldstones encircles the brow of the hill upon which it sits, like the crown on a king's head. Beneath the castle, the lower slopes of the hill are thickly forested. There are gorse, bracken, thistle, sedge and blackberry bushes between pines and grey-green sentinels. Elsewhere skeletal elm, ash and scrub oaks choke the ground like weeds.

Highgarden is surrounded by three rings of white stone whose walls increase in height. Between the outer and middle walls is a famous briar labyrinth which serves to entertain as well as slow invaders. The oldest towers, squat and square, from the Age of Heroes. Newer towers are tall and slender, round fortifications dating from after the Andal invasion. Also within Highgarden's walls are groves, fountains, and courtyards. The castle's godswood contains three weirwoods known as the Three Singers. The palatial keep is decorated with statues and colonnades.

The Nightfort is the largest and oldest castle of the Night's Watch along the Wall, and the only one whose steps up the side of the Wall were carved into the ice. It sits between Icemark to the west and Deep Lake to the east. The castle has been rebuilt hundreds of times.\n\n The Nightfort does not offer the watch as much space to hold men, but gives a much higher fort level than other castles of the Watch. This does come at a higher price though, since the maintenance to keep the castle in good shape is more taxing.

Castle Black is the main stronghold of the Night's Watch and the seat of their Lord Commander. The castle is situated along the Wall between Queensgate to the west and Oakenshield to the east, near the center of the Wall. Castle Black is not a true castle, as it has no walls to defend it to the west, east, or south. Only the Wall stands to the north. It consists of several stone towers and timber keeps. Beneath the keeps and towers, there is a series of subterranean passages called wormwalks which connect all of the buildings.\n\n This unique castle can only be built once its requirements are met. Castle Black was a large project that took hundreds of years to build, and is not available at game start.

Dragonstone is a castle located on the island of the same name at the entrance to Blackwater Bay. Located below the Dragonmont and shaped from stone to look like dragons. The castle has a dark reputation.
